name: Citation abbreviation
description: The citation abbreviation for the court as dictated by Blue Book.

name: Jurisdiction
description: The jurisdiction of the court

name: Appeals to
description: Designates the court that appeals are sent to from this court.

name: Receives appeals from
description: Designates the court or courts that send appeals to this court.

name: Political affiliation
description: A person's primary affiliation with a political party.

name: Docket number
description: A unique identifier assigned by the court to track a specific case.

name: Case name
description: The title of a legal case, usually formatted as Plaintiff v. Defendant, indicating the parties involved.

name: Assigned court
description: The specific court where a case is being heard and managed.

name: Assigned to
description: The judge or magistrate responsible for overseeing and deciding the case.

name: Referred to
description: A situation where a case or a part of it is sent to another judge, magistrate, or court for a specific purpose (e.g., mediation, a magistrate judge’s review).

name: Appeal from
description: The lower court or tribunal from which a case has been appealed.

name: Defendant number
description: A numerical designation used when there are multiple defendants in a case.

name: Parent docket
description: The main case docket to which related cases, motions, or filings are linked.

name: Date filed
description: The official date when a case or legal document was submitted to the court.

name: Date terminated
description: The date when the case was officially closed, whether due to settlement, dismissal, or final judgment.

name: Date last filing
description: The date of the most recent document or motion submitted in the case.

name: Date argued
description: The date when oral arguments were presented before the court.

name: Date re-argued
description: The date when a case was argued again, typically after an appellate court orders a rehearing.

name: Date re-argument denied
description: This refers to the date on which a court formally denies a party's motion to reargue a case, meaning the court has decided not to reconsider its prior ruling.

name: Date certification granted
description: This is the date when a higher court, often an appellate or supreme court, agrees to review a case that was appealed from a lower court. Certification is typically granted when the case presents a significant legal question, conflict between jurisdictions, or an issue of broad public importance.

name: Date certification denied
description: This refers to the date when a higher court declines to review a case, meaning the lower court's decision remains final and binding. Certification is often denied when the court determines that the case does not raise an important legal issue, lacks merit, or does not conflict with existing precedent.

name: Cause
description: The legal reason or basis for a lawsuit, typically referencing the statute, contract, or legal principle under which the claim is brought.

name: Jury demand
description: The compensation demand.

name: Origin
description: Refers to the initial source or cause of a legal dispute or claim, often indicating where the case was first filed or how it originated, such as whether it began in a federal or state court or was initiated by a specific type of complaint.

name: Nature of suit
description: Categorizes the type of legal action being pursued in a case, such as tort, contract, or family law, and is often used in court records to indicate the legal basis of the claim and guide procedural rules and applicable statutes.

name: Jurisdiction
description: The authority of a court to hear a specific case

name: Monetary demand
description: The amount of money a plaintiff is seeking in damages or relief.

name: Arbitration at termination
description: Status of arbitration at the termination of the docket.

name: Plaintiff
description: The party who initiates a lawsuit by filing a complaint against the defendant.

name: Defendant
description: The party being sued or accused in a legal case.

name: Class action status at termination
description: The class action status at the termination of a docket.

name: Procedural progress
description: This refers to the stage or advancement of a case through the legal process, including milestones such as filing motions, conducting discovery, and appearing in hearings, which collectively track the case's movement through the judicial system.

name: Disposition
description: Final resolution of a case, which may include outcomes such as a dismissal, settlement, judgment, or verdict, effectively determining the legal fate of the parties involved in the litigation.

name: Nature of judgement
description: The type or characterization of the court's decision, such as a summary judgment, default judgment, or final judgment, which influences how the ruling is applied and the subsequent rights of the parties.

name: Amount received
description: Dollar amount received (in thousands) when appropriate.

name: Judgement favors
description: Indicates which party in court case the judgement favors

name: Pro se
description: A person who represents themselves in a court proceeding without an attorney. It is Latin for "on one's own behalf" and is commonly seen in both civil and criminal cases.

name: Nature of offense
description: The specific type or category of crime involved in a legal case, such as theft, assault, or fraud, which helps determine the applicable laws, penalties, and procedural rules, as well as guiding the court's understanding of the legal issues at stake.

name: Filing circuit
description: Circuit in which the case was filed.

name: Filing district
description: District court in which the case was filed.

name: Transferred from
description: The docket number of the case in the losing district.

name: Arguments
description: Legal arguments presented during this case.

name: Opinions
description: Opinions resulting from this case

name: Originating docket
description: Lower court docket information associated with appellate cases.

name: Date notice of appeal filed
description: The date the notice of appeal was filed for the case.

name: Date received by court of appeals
description: The date the case was received at the court of appeals.

name: Date disposed
description: The date the case was disposed

name: Date judgement
description: The date of the order or judgment.

name: Ordering judge
description: The judge that issued the final order in the case.

name: Termination reason
description: The reason that a person left a role.

name: Date retired
description: The date when a judge becomes a senior judge by going into active retirement.

name: Sector
description: Sector refers to a distinct segment of the economy or society, typically categorized as either the public sector.

name: Supervisor
description: The supervisor to this position. In the case of a clerkship, the supervising judge.

name: Predecessor
description: The person that previously held this position.

name: Selection method
description: The method used to select a decision

name: Appointed by
description: If this is an appointed position, the person-position responsible for the appointment.

name: Nomination process
description: The process by which an entity is nominated for a role

name: Date nominated
description: The date recorded in the Senate Executive Journal when a federal judge was nominated for their position or the date a state judge nominated by the legislature. When a nomination is by primary election, this is the date of the election. When a nomination is from a merit commission, this is the date the nomination was announced.

name: Judicial Committee actions
description: An action taken by a judicial committee on an issue.

name: Date referred to judicial committee
description: Federal judges are usually referred to the Judicial Committee before being nominated. This is the date of that referral.

name: Date of judicial committee action
description: The date that the Judicial Committee took action on the referral.

name: Date elected
description: Judges are elected in most states. This is the date of their first election. This field will be null if the judge was initially selected by nomination.

name: Date of recess appointment
description: If a judge was appointed while congress was in recess, this is the date of that appointment.

name: Date hearing
description: After being nominated, a judge is usually subject to a hearing. This is the date of that hearing.

name: Date confirmed
description: After the hearing the senate will vote on judges. This is the date of that vote.

name: Vote type
description: The method by which votes were cast toward a decision.

name: Voice vote
description: Whether the Senate voted by voice vote for this position.

name: Votes yes
description: If votes are an integer, this is the number of votes in favor of a position.

name: Votes no
description: If votes are an integer, this is the number of votes opposed to a position.

name: Votes yes (percent)
description: If votes are a percentage, this is the percentage of votes in favor of a position.

name: Votes no (percent)
description: If votes are a percentage, this is the percentage of votes opposed to a position.

name: Case name
description: The title of a legal case, usually formatted as Plaintiff v. Defendant, indicating the parties involved.

name: Date filed
description: The official date when a case or legal document was submitted to the court.

name: Assigned court
description: The specific court where a case is being heard and managed.

name: Authors
description: The author(s) that wrote a particular piece of work.

name: Precedential status
description: A designation indicating whether a court decision serves as binding legal authority for future cases, with precedential opinions guiding lower courts and non-precedential opinions applying only to the specific case.

name: Decision leaning
description: The ideological "direction" of a decision in the Supreme Court database

name: Majority votes
description: The number of justices or judges who agree on the final ruling in a case, forming the controlling opinion that sets the precedent.

name: Minority votes
description: The dissenting votes in a case, representing the judges who disagreed with the majority and may issue a dissenting opinion explaining their reasoning.

name: Posture
description: The procedural posture of the case.

name: Disposition
description: The final outcome of a case as determined by the court, such as "affirmed," "reversed," "remanded," or "dismissed."

name: Citation count
description: The number of times a particular case or legal opinion has been cited in subsequent judicial decisions, indicating its influence on legal precedent.

name: Authorities
description: Authorities refer to the legal sources—such as statutes, case law, constitutional provisions, and administrative regulations—that a court or judge relies upon to justify and support their reasoning. These authorities establish legal precedent and provide the binding or persuasive framework within which the opinion is formulated.

name: Docket
description: A docket is an official court record that lists all the proceedings, filings, and scheduled events in a legal case. It serves as a timeline of the case, tracking motions, hearings, rulings, and other key actions.

name: Judges
description: The judges presiding over a case.

name: Opinions
description: Opinions resulting from this case

name: Case name
description: The title of a legal case, usually formatted as Plaintiff v. Defendant, indicating the parties involved.

name: Date filed
description: The official date when a case or legal document was submitted to the court.

name: Assigned court
description: The specific court where a case is being heard and managed.

name: Authors
description: The author(s) that wrote a particular piece of work.

name: Joined by
description: Judges who shared the perspectives put forth in a court opinion

name: Per curiam
description: A court decision issued collectively and anonymously by the judges or justices, without a single author’s name attached, often used for unanimous or uncontroversial rulings.

name: Opinion group
description: A collection of the opinions put forth by the judges overseeing a case, including various opinion types.

name: Opinion type
description: The classification of a judge’s written opinion based on its role in the ruling. The lead opinion (also called the majority opinion) represents the binding decision of the court, setting legal precedent. A concurring opinion agrees with the majority’s outcome but offers different reasoning or legal interpretation, while a dissenting opinion expresses disagreement with the majority, often providing an alternative legal analysis that may influence future cases.

name: Case name
description: The title of a legal case, usually formatted as Plaintiff v. Defendant, indicating the parties involved.

name: Docket
description: A docket is an official court record that lists all the proceedings, filings, and scheduled events in a legal case. It serves as a timeline of the case, tracking motions, hearings, rulings, and other key actions.

name: Database identifier
description: A unique identier used to designate observations in a database.

name: Political party source
description: The method by which a political affiliation was identified.

name: Citation count
description: The number of times a particular case or legal opinion has been cited in subsequent judicial decisions, indicating its influence on legal precedent.

name: Parenthetical
description: A brief explanatory phrase placed in parentheses within a legal citation to provide context, summarize a holding, or clarify how a cited case is relevant to the argument.

name: Parenthetical score
description: A score between 0 and 1 representing how descriptive the parenthetical is.

name: Panel Judges
description: Panel judges refer to a group of judges who collectively hear and decide a case, typically in appellate courts or specialized tribunals, ensuring diverse legal perspectives and preventing judicial bias. The panel’s decision is usually determined by a majority vote, with dissenting opinions often issued to explain differing legal reasoning.
